reviewText: Hubby and I wanted to watch a new movie, preferably an action adventure thriller to get our heart rates up a bit, because we're sick at home and in need of entertainment capable of counteracting our lethargy. Some people might balk at the more expensive rental fee, but it's cheaper than two theater tickets and we could stay under the covers with hot tea in hand. Perhaps Erased is not as good as The Bourne Identity or Taken, but it's still an interesting intelligence movie and worth the price.
summary: One of the better "special" rentals on Amazon
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: A cross between Bourne and Safe House.Good fast paced action--predictable at times but not overdone.Entertaining but not heart stopping.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I like polar and spy movies.  I enjoy the good plot, the action and the message.  Since I watched "Erased" and "A Good Day to Die Hard" a few days apart, I can easily compare the two films.  Erased is way better; it is well directed with a plot which makes sense as opposed to all the non-sense in the other film.  The action scenes seem real (no super hero but a normal trained agent), and finally the details are accurate unlike the other film where Tchernobyl seems near Moscow. Bottom line, rent or buy it and enjoy the show.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: oh man what lousy movie! the lead character is a plank of wood and his daughter is an insecure little girl who blames daddy for not being there, even when she discovers daddy's been working for the CIA as an Agent!! how stupid is this premise? every time he kills the bad guys she's surprised all over again!!! what?? daddy's a spy and has to kill people to protect us now??? ooh, i don't have any moral reference for this!! "eek daddy, you left me alone when i was a baby!!" boo hooo! and get this, this idiot dad keeps appologising!! "oh honey im so sorry i wasn't there for you, my job and the country's safety are just soooo unimportant compared to your vast and never ending insecurities!" "what was i thinking?? ill tell you what i was thinking, that after you got out of diapers you'd be old enough to understand that daddy's go to work, that i could have been a plumber and you'd be just as empty and stupid, and maybe, just maybe you'll cut me some slack for thinking you'd grow up and quit whining all the time. the more you bitch, the more i want to kill you too!!"
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: This movie  is very similar to the "bourne" movies. It moves quickly, and keeps you guessing.  Aaron Eckhart  plays a dad lost when it comes to connecting with his daughter. The plot forces the two to work together, to stay alive.  In so doing both come around to accepting and  resolving their issues. Aarons character is well thought out, but not so powerful as Jason in the bourne movies. All in all a good movie.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie; however, please be aware, it is also called 'The Expatriate' (which is the title by which I purchased this movie). Erased (The Expatriate) is stylised an old fashioned thriller which pits the wrtiter against the viewer with a good set of actors(actresses) along for the ride. Though some scense are almost somewhat chiche in their presentation, this by no way detracts from the movie which moves along a reasonably quick pace (though not so fast as to wash over the story line and leaving the viewer wondering what just has happened or whether a scene was deleted and left on the cutting room floor). I enjoyed this movie from start to finish, I did not give it 5 stars as it did lack a certain 'WOW' factor but for the opportunity to tune out and enjoy some good TV/DVD then one cannot go far wrong with this film.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: A solid action flick.  Aaron Eckhart is a good actor who elevates the material. The plot is standard ex-spy betrayed, on the run storyline but its enjoyable.  The daughter is annoying at times and SPOILER of course she disappears at the worst time to get herself snatched and then dad to the rescue. Cliches all around but it's worth the rental thanks to solid action and good acting.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Nothing overwhelming or underwhelming about it. Scary because you could imagine if it really happened. Good entertainment. Maybe even worth a second viewing.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: This was a good movie with fresh story. The picture was sharp showed beautiful part of Europe, but I had difficulty with the sound. The sound wasn't clear enough.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Really liked the high speed action and adventure. The mind bending effect of the story line was fascinating and propelling. Always good to see Olga Kurylenko in action, luv her work!!!
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: After his wife dies, ex-CIA agent Ben Logan (Aaron Eckhart) and his estranged daughter (Liana Liberato) settle down to a rocky life. Then one day the company that Bin works for just disappears, along with all the employees. Soon Ben finds that he is also supposed to disappear and his daughter too.As usual now Ben and Amy must learn to trust each other is they are to survive long enough for us to find out who is the cabal behind the dastardly deed.There is lots of fun following the twists and turns of the story. Naturally several times Amy does not stay in the car and hinders Ben's progress. Ben has a nasty habit of dispatching people before getting answers. The plot thickens.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: From the reading on the reverse side of the Blu-ray sounded interesting.  I enjoyed this Blu-ray with all the action, etc.  This is a movie with good action and an interesting plot line.  Not for every one, but many will enjoy this movie.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I had not heard about this movie, but I ordered it because I like the actors.  The movies was GREAT!  Thanks, Amazon!
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: We picked this movie because we like Aaron Eckhart.  It reminded us quite a bit of the Bourne trilogy...  The sound score was similar.  The plot was similar, but instead of Jason and girl [Marie] it is Dad and daughter.  Liana Liberato did a great job as the daughter, very believable and compelling - especially her outbursts about Dad doing bad things and doesn't he know any better.  At times it is a little hard to follow and there are some "leaps of faith" for plausibility.  It does contain the same corrupt good guys are after them plot.  BUT, it was still very entertaining.  I guess it was the evolution of the relationship between Dad and daughter... and filling in the blanks about what happened to Mom.  We're glad we rented it.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: From the beginning of "Erased", the audience  is taken inside the relationship of a father and daughter. The director shows us from the start of the movie that the daughter is tough, but her father is much more so. Because, when she smart mouths him during the breakfast scene, he doesn't even flinch. Her smart mouth, however, serves a purpose, as it lets us know that she's tough, which she'll need to be with a father like hers. Because, as you will soon find out, something bad is going to happen to them.The audience finds out a lot about Ben Logan Aaron Eckhart) during the course of the movie, which is primarily about him. Erased also, concerns family, but even more so, how a father's past can impact his family, in this case, a daughter.Very nice movie. Don't want to give away too much, so will stop  here. Highly recommended.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I expected so much more from this movie. It missing a lot to it. It is very dry and unexciting. The acting is great, but great acting does matter when the content is unfruitful. Even during the action sequences the story was always in a state blandness. I don't recommend seeing it in theaters.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Whole different story line than I was expecting. Excellent story line and acting was in the same category. Would definitely watch again.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I saw this movie as a free offering on my Xbox. I enjoyed the movie as a little above average flick with decent, not stellar acting. Did I enjoy it ?  Sure, but The Bourne Identity is a better action flick. The story has a couple of decent twists, but Kevin Costner's No Way Out has better twists. I'll watch it when it comes on the cable, but probably won't buy the DVD until it hits the $5 barrel at Wal-Mart, but I probably will then. It's a good airplane movie for a short flight.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: We enjoyed this movie after taking a chance on it. We had never heard of it. Mr. Eckhart's presence in the film was the only reason we decided to watch it, after enjoying his performance in "Thank you for Smoking". This is a taut tale of man who finds himself and his daughter cut totally adrift from everything in a foreign country. I appreciated that the characters who appeared 'middle eastern' were not the typical maniacal villains but people who helped strangers. Although there were a few holes in the story line the denouement was satisfying.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Okay, I'll start off by saying I was entertained, hence the four stars, but the movie falls a little short. I've been looking forward to seeing this for a long time, so when the chance recently came up to stream this I did. I love the espionage genre and had high expectations for this film, and it didn't quite meet them. That's not to say the film isn't interesting, but we've seen the formula before in the film "Taken" and countless others, so this is nothing more than a slight variation on that.The other thing that kind of throws this film off is that our super smart hero seems dense a lot of the time.  I'm not exactly sure what that is, but it works against making the film as coherent as it should be. It was predictable, and that's okay as long as the ride to the film's final destination is worth it.  When you've been spoiled by the twists in a Jason Bourne adventure it's hard for other films to reach that level.I try to judge each film on it's own merits, so don't think that I was expecting a Bourne film, I wasn't... I just think the bar could have been set a little higher for this movie.  Still, it's fun to watch.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Just saw this great little thriller with Aaron Eckhardt. While the story is a little bit derivative of other thriller plots you may have seen, this is still a great film, exciting as heck, with some great acting from Eckhardt, and the rest of the cast.Basic storyline is an American Expatriate father caring for  his young teenaged daughter living with him in Belgium. He is working for a corporation as a security expert, and takes his daughter to his office one evening (after he uncovers something the day previously that has him puzzled), all traces of the company he works for, the employees he worked with, and his own employment are erased from existence.  THe next hour and a half involve him figuring out what the heck happened, and why, all by way of chases, shootouts, fights, and good old fashioned intrigue?This is a very good film that I would recommend if you like the the thriller/spy motif.
summary: Very Good Espionage Thriller in the Bourne/Taken Spirit
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: A lot of action.  It has a decent story line and it was well acted.  Not at the top of my list but it still was a good movie.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Though nothing special, ERASED is a watchable thriller about secret and highly corrupt deals with other nations and a rogue agent who suddenly wakes up to find his occupation and entire reason-for-being "erased." It moves fast, sometimes too fast--the pacing could use some work--and too much of the conflict is bluntly explained away in the script. ERASED also relies too much on shoot-'em-ups and punch-'em-outs, and the super-tough former agent who's done some terrible things but is a good guy at heart, blahly and routinely played by Eckhart, manages to beat some pretty unbelievable odds. More in the way of subtleties and layers of intrigue would have made this a much better film.ERASED makes for easy and enjoyable entertainment if you're not in the mood to think too hard. As others have noted, the cinematography is quite good, and the film makes colorful use of its Belgian settings. Some of the supporting cast play their roles pretty convincingly; moreover, the acting/characterization of daughter Amy, played by Liana Liberato, gets better as it goes.
summary: Doesn't Make the CIA Look So Swell
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: This has everything you want in a thriller, including Olga Kurylenko, who you actually want in everything.  Aaron is reliably good and likable, Liana Liberato is perfect as his daughter, but I spent the movie waiting for Olga.  You can see that casting is a science.  If they had Julianne Moore (an actress I love) in that part, I would have skipped it.

Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: The Bourne movies were tremendously successful, so it's no wonder there have been a spate of wannabes. This is a very watchable film but, at the end of the day, it doesn't rise above he fray.Here's the scoop. Ben Logan (Aaron Eckhart) is ex-CIA now working with a a security firm in Brussels to troubleshoot their products. He comes up with an odd finding regarding patents. Now he finds the office he reported to is gone as though it never existed. No recent record of him exists and soon he finds himself on the run with his daughter and fighting for his life.The beginning of this movie is actually very good. You get to see Eckhart as an adviser, his testing of products and the results he gives to his superiors give the viewer an insider's view of what the high stakes security industry involves. When he starts asking questions though you know something's afoot. Then, when his co-workers begin showing up dead, and he hightails it with his daughter, it devolves into a rather typical cat and mouse outing. The Belgium settings give it that 'international intrigue' bit of flavor and help show off Eckhart's ability to move and make things happen. This is shot well, acted well enough (Eckhart isn't digging deep here) and generally well executed all the way around. The story moves at an even clip and much of it makes sense (save for the cheesy, terrible ending) but it has some tough acts to follow. You don't put Lucifer's Friend on stage after Led Zeppelin.This is a steady, entertaining watch. But after it's ended you won't be rushing in for a second viewing.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Don't waste your money on this rental. The sound track is just horrible. Even turning up the sound system and/or the TV does not help the imbalance. The dialogue is almost whisper like and we just could not hear it. We turned the movie off after 43 minutes in total frustration. I have not had this problem with any other Amazon Instant Video rental before. Very frustrating and I want a full refund of my rental price from Amazon. I see now that other viewers had the same problem so it is a problem with the video itself - not with my TV or sound system. Amazon should pull this one from the listing.

Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: The true star of this better than average espionage thriller is Belgium. Shot in Antwerp and Brussels the cities are extraordinarily beautiful, written by Arash Amel and directed by Philipp Stölzl - both of whom are young and new to the business and it shows.Ben Logan (Aaron Eckhart in a solid performance) is an ex-CIA agent employed by a huge conglomerate Halgate and working for one of their subsidiary companies as a security engineer. He has invited his daughter Amy (Liana Liberato) to move from the US to Belgium to live with him to reconnect after a lengthy separation. Ben's job is to try to get pass security protocols, fool the eye scanners and break into safes. But overnight Ben discovers that his company, Halgate, no longer inhabits his workplace and that all evidence of Ben's existence has been erased. Slowly he discovers that there is a huge conspiracy surrounding his employer and that soon he and his daughter will become subjects of a manhunt. Ben's co-workers are all murdered with the exception of his colleague Derek Kolper (Neil Napier) who apparently has possession of documents that will bring the conspiracy into the open. Ben relies on his US operative colleague Anna Brandt (the beautiful Ukrainian actress Olga Kurylenko) who is not who she seems. Amy grows from being a dysfunctional disgruntled teenager to a keen `agent' with some help from her boyfriend Nabil (the very bright handsome new rising star Yassine Fadel). Targeted for termination by a company with seemingly unlimited recourses, they only have one choice: get to the bottom of this conspiracy in a hope that it will save their lives.Though there are holes in this story and many borrowed concepts from other films in this genre, the film provides visual if not intellectual excitement. The cast is solid and there is always the magnificent beauty of Belgium to fill in the gaps. Who knows how it will fare when it reaches the theaters, but for now it provides a solid at home evening of entertainment. Grady Harp, April 13
summary: Far from home. Far from safe. Far from over.

Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Erased centers on security expert Ben Logan (Aaron Eckhart) and his daughter, Amy (Liana Liberato), who live in Belgium after Ben left his wife in the States. One day, Ben is presenting flaws in a billion-dollar security system that he plans to work out with his colleagues, but the next day when he returns to work, the office is stripped and abandoned; his entire life for six months is completely erased. Now, on the run with his daughter, Ben works to find out why he's been erased, and along the way, reveals dark secrets about his past.Erased is a thriller that is far from original, but is happily a semi-fresh take on the reworked plot-line. The direction of Philipp Stolzl is actually very well-done, having a some-what calm feeling in this very urgent crisis instead of a constant feeling of impending doom and danger. Sure, the action and intensity are there, but even some action-thrillers make the calm moments feel intensified, as if time is running out by the millisecond. Aaron Eckhart is great, as he is with most of his movies. Here, his character felt like a cross between Jason Statham's Luke Wright (from 2012's Safe) and Liam Neeson's Bryan Mills (Taken); this is a good thing, by the way. Olga Kurylenko was very good as Anna, an old flame and CIA operative who had worked with Ben before, but is now on the other side. Liana Liberato was good as Ben's daughter Amy, but nothing truly gripping or captivating. Sure, we felt for her, but it wasn't tears. If it were Dakota Fanning here instead, then we might have just created the new Niagara Falls (I'm not saying Liana is a bad actress, but she could have done a wee bit better). The script was good, nothing award-winning or really new, but the climax of the movie was just stunning. The way it was shot, the slow-burning build-up, it was just fantastic.Erased is not an original thriller, but it is a damn good one to add to your movie collection if you like action-thrillers, political-espionage thrillers or a good chase film. Eckhart is in top-form here, and gets to show off some really awesome fighting skills. I'm just disappointed this wasn't released in theaters nationwide; I would have paid to see it.4/5 Stars****
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I do wish we could rate with half stars.  On my scale, 3 stars means a movie is a must rent on home video, and might possibly be worth buying.  This is an overall entertaining spy thriller in the tradition of the Bourne films, just not nearly as good.  It slows down a bit too much in the middle, and the actors are far from Hollywood's A list.Still, if you're in the mood for a decent flick, this one will entertain.  But if you never get around to it, you're not missing too much.  I rate it two and a half starts.*  = This movie is bad.  You'll have more fun getting a root canal.**  = This movie is passable.  If you're bored, you might find it somewhat entertaining.***  = This is a solid movie, definitely worth renting, possibly worth buying.****  = This is a must see on the big screen and a must own on home video.***** = This is one of the greatest films of all time, a serious contender for Best Picture.

Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Note: May contain spoilers. Proceed with caution.Have you ever seen a movie that seemed so familiar you could swear you've seen it before? Well, that was my experience with Erased (aka The Expatriate outside the U.S.) Taking obvious influences from many action-thrillers that preceded it, Erased, like Ben Logan (Aaron Eckhart), suffers from a lack of identity. While interesting at times, the story being told is one we've seen many times before and, in some cases, it's been done better. With that being said, though, the film still managed to hold my attention despite its derivative nature and when it was all said and done I actually had a good time.You follow the life of Ben Logan and his daughter Amy (Liana Liberato). Ben is an ex-CIA agent and because of this he made sure that Amy wasn't a huge part of his life while she was growing up. I guess in his eyes having no father was better than having a father who worked 24/7. Anyway, the two of them wind up on the run after Ben goes to work one day only to find that the company had vanished. As a confused Ben tries to put the pieces together, a government conspiracy unravels which forces these two to literally fight for their life.Truth be told, I knew very little about this film going in. I had seen a trailer beforehand, but beyond that I went in pretty blind. For me, the most unfortunate thing about this movie is how much promise it had. You see, it is possible to make great films regardless of whether or not they draw from previous works, but you need to add something different tot he mix. Well, in Erased's starting moments I was convinced that I was going to receive just that. While the broken father/daughter relationship is a bit overdone, Eckhart and Liberato had some great chemistry and it seemed as if the film was setting itself up for something amazing. It didn't take long for things to fall apart, though.One or two cliches here and there are ok, but within the first 30 minutes I was slapped with every action-thriller cliche in the book. Unfortunately, I can't even say that it stopped there. Not only is his relationship with his daughter rocky, he's a CIA agent. Not only is he late to his daughter's award ceremony, the man at his work is secretly working for the people trying to set him up. Not only did he split up with the mother of his child, she never told Amy why or what he did. The cliches kept coming and it reached a point where it became too much. Still, as much as I seemingly disliked this movie so far, I continued on. Why? Well, I don't have an answer for that. It's probably because I try to give every movie the benefit of the doubt and this is probably a character flaw of mine.Anyway, as cliched as the scenes were, the bits with Ben and Amy were actually the most enjoyable sequences in the film. It wasn't until the writer's attempted to get technical with the outside workings of the organization that I really wanted to pull my hair out. Now I'm a fairly intelligent guy, but nothing seemed to make any sense. All the hard details about his previous job never felt important or authentic. It was almost as if they were thrown in at the last minute. It's like the writers realized that a backstory is important, but they didn't think about it until they were already in the process of filming. The only thing these scenes really accomplished was destroying the crippled flow that was built up by the previous scenes with Ben and Amy.Now up to this point I've kind of torn this movie to shreds, but it's not all bad. In fact, it's not bad at all. It's just very underwhelming. With that said, though, Erased did manage to create some pretty intense action sequences and the acting was solid as well. While the action scenes may not have been extremely innovative, they always kept me on my toes. The fighting didn't feel stiff and the scenes never felt like they were dragged on for too long. They were in, they were out, and they were moving on. Also, Eckhart and Liberato performed really well in the scenes they were in together. While most of the supporting cast never felt important, these two really did a good job of bringing these characters to life.Finally, the score, composed by Jeff Danna, was... inconsistent, at best. Like majority of the elements present in the movie, the score borrows from things we've heard from in the past. Majority of the time I didn't even notice it was there because none of the compositions really stood out to me, but there were a few notable exceptions. For example, the piece heard in the final scene leading into the credits was really well done, but other than that most of it was just background noise.Overall Score: 6/10 - Personally, had they focused more on Ben and Amy and less on the CIA then this score would probably be higher. With the chemistry they had on screen there was a lot of potential to do something amazing, but in the end they just settled for something average. The story isn't anything to write home about and there's a ton of cliches, but the acting was solid and the fight scenes were entertaining. Part of me wishes there was something substantial for me to really love this movie, but alas this is what we were given.
Title: The Expatriate

Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: expatriate: Residing in a different country while maintaining citizenship of your native homeland.An enjoyable high octane action flick utilizing a cookie-cutter screenplay. Yes, it is a formula product, but surprisingly even productions that rip from the blueprint often screw up. Having been able to, at the very least, overcome the astounding amount of inane and worthless flicks that populate the cinematic landscape nowadays is in itself a success. This tracked true to the recipe, so I would categorize it as very solid.Preface caveat: Aaron Eckart is one of those performers that I seemingly cannot connect with on any level. He has all the hallmarks of a quality actor - projection, presence, and personality. Yet for all those talents - I can't seem to find common ground. And I honestly can't explain why.That said, I found his performance in this production surprisingly engaging and quite entertaining. Hopefully it's a trend.In 'Expatriate' he plays Ben Logan, tech security specialist. Hired by a global security company for his expertise - breaking into previously thought of unhackable systems - exposing vulnerabilities, weaknesses and flaws in their product lines.To showcase his level of commitment to the company, Ben chooses to stay overseas in order to work at the Belgian offices of the corporation. Along with him is his young daughter Amy, although she isn't nearly as pleased with her new status as an expatriate. But the death of her mother back in the states left no other choice. Having had little contact with her father since birth, the incongruent pair are just now learning to adjust to one another; her dad's comfortable paycheck acting as a stable platform for their fresh start, making the transition bearable.Until the day that his company literally disappears.Everyone he knew is gone. The office he has been going to daily for the past six months is stripped bare, his fellow employees vanished. Everything a modern person uses to define a life no longer exists for Logan - no bank account, no money, no digital records, no identification, nothing. Not even his cell phone, which is company property, works anymore. His existence has been erased.Just what's going on?As father and daughter are caught up in a bizarre and terrifying world of espionage and twisted corporate shadows, they're forced on the run. With little or no break, they have to stay one step in front of professional assassins and various spy agencies looking to put them into a set of anonymous graves.There were some weaknesses in the film that have to be acknowledged.Young co-star Liana Liberato's character as Amy was often artificially too self-aware. For someone who projected typical adolescent immaturity at the beginning of the film, to then flip a switch and become a strong and emotionally composed character - i.e. The driving sequence/interrogation - was ridiculous. And certain aspects of the script rang false; particularly when the intelligence officers gather to discuss the true situation of Ben Logan.Still, those minor criticisms were mostly forgivable when balanced out with the enjoyable heart-thumping pace of the movie.Overall, you'll enjoy this if you can imagine Jason Bourne with a kid.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I was kind of bummed out that I was not able to get dvd to play on my dvd player, but was able to view movie through my laptop.I am a big fan of Aaron Eckhart so the purchase was very worth it.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewerName: Mark Eremite "This Is A Display Model Only"
reviewText: I'm a fan of Aaron Eckhart. I think he's got more leading man status than it seems like most movie producers are willing to give him credit for, because if he's not playing second fiddle in big-budget fare, then he's playing front-runner on derivative B-grade shlock like this.Shlock is harsh, I'll admit. The film isn't bad, per se. It's just doesn't try to transcend beyond any of the usual spy/thriller cliches that dominate the genre. Eckhart plays Logan, an ex-CIA operative who works for a security company by searching for flaws in their various safety/lock-em-up devices. One day, after a rough night with his daughter, Amy, Logan returns to his company to find that not only is it gone, but so is every single piece of evidence proving that he's worked for them. Wha happa?!Turns out the company wasn't what it seemed to be, and so begins the movie's long spiral into predictability. What could've been a taut action-paced thriller is crippled by a needlessly convoluted plot. Those extraneous twists and turns are there, I suspect, to detract from the fact that the screenwriter couldn't really come up with any inventive or clever ways for Logan to show off his CIA skills, and so we are left with happenstance, silly levels of brutality, and tedium to make up for the gap.To distract from this there is also a paper-thin romantic subplot (involving a female CIA agent who may as well have been a mannequin for as detailed as her character was). Plus there is the traditionally annoying teenage-daughter-doesn't-get-along-with-Daddy subplot. Please, for the love of God, can Hollywood get some screenwriters who know how to create teenage characters? They don't all have to be entitled, self-important, irrational whiners, do they? Of course, Logan having to lug Amy everywhere complicates things, but not in a way that's tense or intriguing. Instead, Amy shows preternatural skill at detection and evading when it furthers the plot, and she shows an agonizing level of idiocy and pubescence when the story is in danger of going too fast. (What's this? Logan and Amy have successfully evaded death and capture for twenty minutes? Well, then it's about time for Amy, for no reason whatsoever, to have a tantrum about how her uber-skilled father is a bad person so that she can storm away to be on her own and get caught.)Throw in a handful of characters that have as much depth and complexity as a Barbie doll, add some grade-school level espionage tricks (the kind Encyclopedia Brown might employ), and an ending that may as well have been scored by a punctured balloon sputtering around a room, and you have a film that -- even if it couldn't have been amazing -- could've still risen above its final, mediocre offering. Worth it for the first half, but keep the Hoover ready because, by the final credits, you're guaranteed to have thrown more than one handful of popcorn at the screen.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: There is nothing new in this video.  It is a cut and paste of many other moves, videos.  Stronger acting would have helped!
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: it's parts of several movies: "Taken", a Jason Borne character movie, just about anything with Jason Statham in it, etc.  Aaron Eckhart is poised to be the next middle-aged male action star, and he should be, he pulls it off well.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Story sounds a bit cliche, movie is actually anything but.  Tense and suspenseful, it was a pleasant surprise.  Aaron Eckhart has shown time and time again that hes a truly worthy leading man.  I hope at some point hell finally gain the respect and stature he deserves.  This guy truly deserves to be a leading man a lot more than he gets to thus far.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I am a big Aaron Eckhart fan so I decided to fork over $10.99 to watch this movie before its in theaters.The first half was good and the 2nd half the movie fell apart.  It is as if they built it up and rushed the ending.  It was very predictable and was almost very similar to Taken 2 at the end.  This is not worth the money, wait for this one to hit paid cable stations and watch then.
summary: Not Worth the $10.99 for this one!
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: See after a cup of coffee and feel the rush. Eckhart is an engaging actor even when he is just picking up the paycheck
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: This is a very familiar plot line, father in national security business and estranged from daughter who does not know this and who just happens to be with him in a foreign country when a strange occurrence puts them on the run, but if that is what you are looking for, this does good except Eckhart's character is just a little too simplistic at heart.
summary: Standard fair, but reasonably well done
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: This is so predictable and extremely uninteresting. The description basically gives you the story line and it just gets more boring from there. I fell asleep 30-40 minutes into it and had to finish it the next morning (could have slept in and not missed a thing). Not even worth the rental. BTW if you have Netflix it is there in HD.
summary: A knockoff of a few better movies
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: A very good movie. Lots of action. Will watch it again and again. Great movie and  loved the cast. Thanks
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Exceptionally good movie. Great plot and and ample action. I also look forward to buying this DVD when it comes on sale.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Arron Eckhart has been someone to watch since Battle: Los Angles, as the tough Marine sergeant. Having liked the movie very much I've decided to check into this one. It was great. The enemy is over rated as being the CIA. Then every one is after him and his daughter, because he's the last one alive who worked on a project they didn't know was funded by the CIA. I hope in his next movie the CIA is played as what they really are, an information gathering agency, who cannot work their stuff on American soil. They are not a real James Bond.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Considering the amount of money it costs us to go to a decent theater with recliner like seats and watch this movie, (which we don't do anymore) it was well worth $9 to watch it in the comfort and safety of our own home. I have a 42" LCD Visio for just that reason.We both like Aaron Eckhart's work, and this was up to his previous standards at least. The writing was well done, but there was a problem with the sound. And I know it's in the film not Amazon Instant Video. Some "background" sounds and music made it hard to hear dialog.Worth $9 to see before release...YES.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: This is a very well done thriller. Aaron Eckhart gives his usual top drawer performance. Liana Liberato's performance is nothing to sneeze at. She is convincing from the start. She created a very compelling character. Well worth your time and money to weatch.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: 1st. -- This particular version is in Italian or Spanish.  I don't remember.  But you can select "English" version.in the settings.  But its a minor hassle.The movie however, is well done.  It kinda is similar to the BOURNE genre.  Many scenes and techniques are very reminiscent of Bourne Ulitimatum.  I was very pleased with the screenplay.  I was not bored at any time.  The story addresses real life situations in the intelligence communities, and for this reason the Title was changed and its getting snubbed by the media.  Very intelligent challenge your powers of problem solving.  A film that you will want to watch again and so worth buying.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Being an Aaron Eckhart fan he didn't disappoint me. I love all his movies.  He really is a great actor.
summary: Any movie with Eckhart is awesome in my eyes
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Aaron Eckhart brings his daughter up to his CIA European headquarters only to find that the office is abandoned, and all of his coworkers are dead in the local morgue.  Aaron tries to keep his daughter safe while figuring out who killed all of his workmates, and uncovers the plot to get rid of him.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: The protagonist (an attractive and at least somewhat athletic male) works for a powerful and amoral corporation or covert agency.  He stumbles upon some information he's not supposed to know, and his employer pulls out all the stops to have him "erased" - his workplace and colleagues disappear, his cell phone and credit cards stop working, and people are trying to kill him.  Against incredible odds, he must survive on the run, solve the mystery of why this is happening, and ultimately topple the conspiracy to get the bad guy.Sound familiar?  You've probably seen several movies with the same plot.  The details are different.  The protagonist in this case has a teenage daughter, and the setting is Belgium.Aside from the recycled plot, the movie is otherwise competently crafted, fast-paced, and reasonably entertaining.Rent, don't buy.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: It was good in thought, but not overall. It was way too long and for Aaron ekhart was not a leading man type material. Not for me anyway, no offense to him.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: The daughter was so annoying. Ridiculously so. She was so upset that her father was an ex special OPS CIA agent, could kill people with his bare hands and basically beat up anyone that followed them. Her father spoke Russian, English, French, etc. etc. This was a problem for her. She lived in Belgium. This was a problem for her. She was spoiled. This was a problem for her. She wasn't given 100% attention. This was a problem for her.This movie would have been great with more Olga K and less stupid daughter.
summary: Could have done without the Daughter
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Purchased this on Blu-ray as I'm an avid fan of spy/secret agent thrillers. I had low expectations as previous reviews have bashed this movie. I like Aaron Eckhart as an action actor. He played the role well, however I think the script fell shy as if the writers had "writer's block" on some of lines. The movie has a nice Bourne feel as Aaron's character is dealing with a government conspiracy that pits him and his daughter against The CIA. The close combat sequences were well executed. Felt like he really was a "retired" special agent as he does get his a** handed to him a couple times. I enjoyed it and glad I could add it the collection. I just felt it was lacking in some parts so I give I a C+/B-.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I liked this movie.  It's the type of story line I haven't seen in awhile. It's fast moving and keeps your interest without a problem.  The ending is.....well, not what I had hoped for, none the less it's not a bad ending.  Watch it and see if you agree.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: I was neither thrilled or disappointed that's why I rated as I did.  In this day and age with all the trailers, etc. out there,you get what you want.  I think you need to update your guidelines and remove DVD's from your listing.  Personally, Iwouldn't recommended this DVD, that's my perspective.  I have and intend to keep getting my DVD from Amazon.com,(Prime) two day free shipping, but I getting tired of these stupid questions about DVD's and batteries.  Other Products I can understand, you need to do some work on your rating/feedback vehicle.  Common sense would be a great start.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: This movie is an action type movie that could have been more realistic had it not been for the girl not trying to get away several times, knowing that if she did, she is as good as dead.  Would I see it again??  Probably not.
summary: Not bad but not great either
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: A little B movie like in it's presentation. Very much a copy of the Bourne movie series but not nearly as good cinematography !
summary: Weak version of the Bourne series !!
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Even thou I love the actors playing in this movie I wasn't all that impressed with the performances. I had higher expectations
Title: The Expatriate

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: Ben Logan (Aaron Eckhart) works for a security testing company in Belgium.  His teen daughter, Amy (Liana Liberato)attends high school. One day when Ben goes to work he finds out his company is missing and never existed.Being a former CIA agent, Ben investigates. He ends up on the lam battling the CIA, authorities, and a corporation that all want him and his daughter dead. Amy quickly goes from a snarky teen to Internet sleuth.The film consists of a lot of double agents. The twists are shown to the audience which takes away from any mystery aspect. It is the "Bourne" type of film with one man against the system. This one has the addition of a daughter.This is a fairly decent film for those who like the "Bourne" type of film, especially if your thirst was not satisfied with that latest 4th "Bourne" installment.
summary: MR. LOGAN. YOU HAVE NEVER WORKED FOR THIS COMPANY.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: This film was fascinating.  Seriously, it was "Taken" with everything fixed.  It's about a spy with a daughter.  Something goes wrong with his work and she gets grabbed.  There is more to the story of course but really everything I thought was horrible in Taken never happened in this movie.  If you want the story this is the good version.  Everything was better. Everything.  The plot, the writing, acting directing even the lighting was better. Not crazy about the poster though.
summary: Imagine the movie "Taken" where nothing was stupid.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: It's in the mold of  "Taken" where a father who just happens to be an ex-spy moves to Europe with his teenage daughter to work for a high tech security firm but is duped and then left out in the cold and on the run. Eckhart gives a good performance. I would say it was worth the rent.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: The story was constructed and written very professionally, also the actors fit and played their parts well. Not till half way through the video did you find out the Hero was a hit man for the CIA and his daughter was first scared, then mad then supportive. She vaccinated through these mood several times during the movie. I feel the Violence was limited to only 4 or 5 short scenes. It has the quaint essential car chase scenes, and fights with the "bad guys" at the end. The movie had two GREAT ending scenes so your were first sad about the ending then very happy when a surprise ending scene turns thing around. Great movie, I rented the video and plan to buy it on Amazon soon.
summary: One of the top CIA movies ever
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: "Someone erased my e-mail, my phone records, my life." Ben Logan (Eckhart) is living and working in Belgium when his daughter comes to live with him. She is not having a good time at all and lets him know. When Ben gets an e-mail from his work telling him to stop in and pick something up he is surprised when the building he works at is empty and no one knows anything about it. When he finds out that all the people he worked with are dead and he is the next target he must find a way to save him and his daughter as well as find out the truth. This is a good movie and is worth watching but isn't really as exciting as the plot sounds. The movie is very tense at times and really keeps you watching. The easiest way to describe the movie is a mix of Mission Impossible, Eraser, and The Net. The only thing that really bugged me in this was the daughter. She seemed to be bi-polar, really wanting her dad to help, then next second being mad that he did. Watch and you will see what I mean. Overall, this is very much worth seeing. It does seem to slow down in some parts but I do recommend this. I give it a B.
summary: A tense thriller that is worth watching. I liked it but it did seem slow in some parts. Mission Impossible meets The Net. B
Title: The Expatriate

reviewText: Erased doesn't have the budget or the kinetic energy of Taken, but once the action gets going it is an interesting actioneer.  The plot is recycled from Bourne, Taken, Salt and History of Violence, so it does allow the audience to root for Eckhart.
Title: The Expatriate

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: If "Erased" had been made 30 years ago it might have seemed a novel thriller but in the wake of what's come before, this thriller starring Aaron Eckhart leaves the same light lingering impression as a mistake erased from a piece of paper. "Erased" is little more than "Taken" with a bit of "Safe House" and other spy thrillers thrown into the mix and as derivative as they come.Eckhart plays Ben Logan a former CIA operative and killer who has "retired" working now as a security consultant in Antwerp. He has his daughter Amy (Liana Liberato) living with him after the death of his ex-wife. It's a somewhat uneasy existence as the two are still working out their differences and how to live together peacefully. One morning Logan goes into work to discover that his division has never existed; what's more all of his co-workers are in the morgue. Suddenly, Logan and his daughter are on the run themselves with an assassin on their trail and Ben must piece together what happened and who is behind the conspiracy to erase his existance.Eckhart makes a fine action thriller hero and is a terrific actor. I can only suspect that the timing of the project, the chance to shoot overseas and have a vacation and the price was right. Actors, after all, have to (and like to) work and I'm sure that "Erased" looked fine on paper. It is a decent thriller it's just not something we haven't seen a dozen times before and done better on a larger budget.The film is ably directed by Phillip Stoizi and the screenplay by Arash Amel (who just completed scripting the sequel toI Am Legend [Blu-ray]) certainly does a good job of developing the father-daughter relationship between the two main characters. Where the film falls down is in the lack of originality of its execution as well as the twist and turns of the plot.What makes "Erased" memorable is Eckhart's dependable performance as an actor everything else is recycled and derivative from better made films.
summary: If this Aaron Eckhart thriller was erased no one would notice (review of the on-demand version)
Title: The Expatriate
